author: Steve Martin
blurb: Martin is an American actor, comedian, writer, playwright, producer, musician, and composer.

author: J.R.R. Tolkien
blurb: Tolkien was Rawlinson and Bosworth Professor of Anglo-Saxon at Oxford from 1925 to 1945, and Merton Professor of English language and literature from 1945 to 1959.

author: Stephenie Meyer
blurb: I was born in Connecticut in 1973, during a brief blip in my family's otherwise western U.S. existence.

author: J.D. Salinger
blurb: Salinger was an American author, best known for his 1951 novel The Catcher in the Rye, as well as his reclusive nature.

author: Madeleine L'Engle
blurb: L'Engle was an American writer best known for her Young Adult fiction, particularly the Newbery Medal-winning A Wrinkle in Time and its sequels A Wind in the Door, A Swiftly Tilting Planet, and Many Waters.

author: Helen Keller
blurb: Keller was obstinate, prone to fits of violence, and seething with rage at her inability to express herself.

author: Ayn Rand
blurb: Alisa Rosenbaum was born in pre-revolutionary St. Petersburg to a prosperous Jewish family.

author: Mother Teresa
blurb: Blessed Teresa of Calcutta, or Mother Teresa, born Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu was an Albanian Roman Catholic nun who founded the Missionaries of Charity in Kolkata (Calcutta), India in 1950. For over forty years she ministered to the poor, sick, orphaned, and dying, while guiding the Missionaries of Charity's expansion, first throughout India and then in other countries.By the 1970s she had become internationally famed as a humanitarian and advocate for the poor and helpless, due in part to a documentary, and book, Something Beautiful for God by Malcolm Muggeridge.

author: George Bernard Shaw
blurb: Shaw was an Irish playwright, socialist, and a co-founder of the London School of Economics.

author: Dr. Seuss
blurb: Theodor Seuss Geisel was born 2 March 1904 in Springfield, MA. He graduated Dartmouth College in 1925, and proceeded on to Oxford University with the intent of acquiring a doctorate in literature.

author: James Baldwin
blurb: Baldwin was an American novelist, essayist, playwright, poet, and social critic.

author: W.C. Fields
blurb: Fields was born William Claude Dukenfield, the eldest of five children.

author: Thomas A. Edison
blurb: Edison was an American inventor, scientist and businessman who developed many devices that greatly influenced life around the world, including the phonograph, the motion picture camera, and a long-lasting, practical electric light bulb.

author: Eleanor Roosevelt
blurb: Roosevelt was an American political leader who used her influence as an active First Lady from 1933 to 1945 to promote the New Deal policies of her husband, President Franklin D.

author: Terry Pratchett
blurb: Sir Terry Pratchett sold his first story when he was thirteen, which earned him enough money to buy a second-hand typewriter. His first novel, a humorous fantasy entitled The Carpet People, appeared in 1971 from the publisher Colin Smythe.

author: E.E. Cummings
blurb: Cummings was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on October 14, 1894.

author: Martin Luther King Jr.
blurb: Jr. was one of the pivotal leaders of the American civil rights movement.

author: Harper Lee
blurb: Lee was a tomboy and a precocious reader, and enjoyed the friendship of her schoolmate and neighbor, the young Truman Capote.

author: George Eliot
blurb: In 1819, novelist George Eliot (nee Mary Ann Evans), was born at a farmstead in Nuneaton, Warwickshire, England, where her father was estate manager. Mary Ann, the youngest child and a favorite of her father's, received a good education for a young woman of her day.

author: Jorge Luis Borges
blurb: Borges was fluent in several languages.

author: Suzanne Collins
blurb: Librarian Note: There is more than one author in the Goodreads database with this name.Since 1991, Suzanne Collins has been busy writing for children’s television. She has worked on the staffs of several Nickelodeon shows, including the Emmy-nominated hit Clarissa Explains it All and The Mystery Files of Shelby Woo.

author: George Carlin
blurb: Carlin was a Grammy-winning American stand-up comedian, actor, author, and philosopher.

author: Charles M. Schulz
blurb: Schulz was an American cartoonist, whose comic strip Peanuts proved one of the most popular and influential in the history of the medium, and is still widely reprinted on a daily basis.

author: Jane Austen
blurb: Austen was an English novelist whose works of romantic fiction, set among the landed gentry, earned her a place as one of the most widely read writers in English literature, her realism and biting social commentary cementing her historical importance among scholars and critics.

author: Douglas Adams
blurb: Adams was an English author, comic radio dramatist, and musician.

author: William Nicholson
blurb: Nicholson was born in 1948, and grew up in Sussex and Gloucestershire.

author: Marilyn Monroe
blurb: Monroe was ranked as the sixth greatest female star of all time by the American Film Institute.

author: George R.R. Martin
blurb: Martin was born September 20, 1948, in Bayonne, New Jersey.

author: Khaled Hosseini
blurb: Hosseini was born in Kabul, Afghanistan, in 1965.

author: André Gide
blurb: Gide was a French author and winner of the Nobel Prize in literature in 1947.

author: C.S. Lewis
blurb: CLIVE STAPLES LEWIS (1898–1963) was one of the intellectual giants of the twentieth century and arguably one of the most influential writers of his day. He was a Fellow and Tutor in English Literature at Oxford University until 1954.

author: Albert Einstein
blurb: Einstein was born in Ulm, Germany.

author: Jimi Hendrix
blurb: Hendrix was an American guitarist, singer and songwriter.

author: Alfred Tennyson
blurb: Tennyson was born in Somersby, Lincolnshire, the fourth of the twelve children of George Tennyson, clergyman, and his wife, Elizabeth.

author: Ernest Hemingway
blurb: Hemingway was an American author and journalist.

author: Haruki Murakami
blurb: Haruki Murakami (Japanese: 村上 春樹) is a popular contemporary Japanese writer and translator. His work has been described as 'easily accessible, yet profoundly complex'.

author: Bob Marley
blurb: Robert "Bob" Nesta Marley OM was a Jamaican singer, songwriter, guitarist, and activist. He was the frontman, lead singer, songwriter and guitarist for the ska, rocksteady and reggae bands: The Wailers (1964 – 1974) and Bob Marley & the Wailers (1974 - 1981).

author: Elie Wiesel
blurb: Wiesel was a Romania-born American novelist, political activist, and Holocaust survivor of Hungarian Jewish descent.

author: J.M. Barrie
blurb: Sir James Matthew Barrie, 1st Baronet, OM (9 May 1860 – 19 June 1937) was a Scottish author and dramatist, best remembered today as the creator of Peter Pan.The child of a family of small-town weavers, he was educated in Scotland. He moved to London, where he developed a career as a novelist and playwright.

author: Charles Bukowski
blurb: Bukowski was the only child of an American soldier and a German mother.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
blurb: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche (1844–1900) is a German philosopher of the late 19th century who challenged the foundations of Christianity and traditional morality. He was interested in the enhancement of individual and cultural health, and believed in life, creativity, power, and the realities of the world we live in, rather than those situated in a world beyond.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
blurb: Emerson was born in Boston.

author: J.K. Rowling
blurb: Rowling was born to Peter James Rowling, a Rolls-Royce aircraft engineer, and Anne Rowling (née Volant), on 31 July 1965 in Yate, Gloucestershire, England, 10 miles (16 km) northeast of Bristol.

author: Mark Twain
blurb: Samuel Langhorne Clemens, better known by his pen name Mark Twain, was an American author and humorist. He is noted for his novels Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1885), called "the Great American Novel", and The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876).Twain grew up in Hannibal, Missouri, which would later provide the setting for Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer.

author: Alexandre Dumas-fils
blurb: Alexandre Dumas (son) was born in Paris, France, the illegitimate child of Marie-Laure-Catherine Labay (1794-1868), a dressmaker, and novelist Alexandre Dumas. During 1831 his father legally recognized him and ensured that the young Dumas received the best education possible at the Institution Goubaux and the Collège Bourbon.

author: Garrison Keillor
blurb: Keillor was born in Anoka, Minnesota, the son of Grace Ruth (née Denham) and John Philip Keillor, who was a carpenter and postal worker.

author: Pablo Neruda
blurb: Neruda was the pen name and, later, legal name of the Chilean writer and politician Neftalí Ricardo Reyes Basoalto.

author: Allen Saunders
blurb: Saunders was an American writer, journalist and cartoonist who wrote the comic strips Steve Roper and Mike Nomad, Mary Worth and Kerry Drake.

author: Jim Henson
blurb: Henson was the most widely known puppeteer in American television history.

author: John Lennon
blurb: John Winston Ono Lennon, MBE, was an English singer-songwriter who rose to worldwide fame as one of the founding members of The Beatles, and together with Paul McCartney formed one of the most successful songwriting partnerships of the 20th century.Born and raised in Liverpool, Lennon became involved in the skiffle craze as a teenager, his first band, The Quarrymen, evolving into The Beatles in 1960. As the group began to undergo the disintegration that led to their break-up towards the end of that decade, Lennon launched a solo career that would span the next decade, punctuated by critically acclaimed albums, including John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band and Imagine, and iconic songs such as "Give Peace a Chance" and "Imagine".Lennon revealed a rebellious nature and acerbic wit in his music, his writing, on film, and in interviews, and became controversial through his work as a peace activist.
